blog.description: I'm a father of two young daughters. They both love Pokémon. Each day I doodle one on their lunch napkins, then share with the world. Please share 😉.

caption:
Sorry for the lack of napkins the last week or two. I took a new role at my office and things have been crazy. Plus, spring break was last week. Anyhoo. Here’s a pikachu my oldest wanted in her lunch.
.
.

summary: Inyssa: I’m the best and fuck anyone who says otherwise. Literally anyone: Hey you’re pretty cool. Inyssa: Shut the fuck up how...
body:
Inyssa: I’m the best and fuck anyone who says otherwise.

Literally anyone: Hey you’re pretty cool.

Inyssa: Shut the fuck up how dare you compliment me everyone knows I’m the worst person on the face of the Earth don’t ever say something like that again.

title: Sandile - 551
body:
It moves along below the sand’s surface, except for its nose and eyes. A dark membrane shields its eyes from the sun.

- Pokemon White, X, Omega Ruby

blog.name: gym-leaders-in-the-making
blog.title: A blog for Pokémon challenges
blog.description: Mostly Monotype, because nuzlockes are pure grinding.

tags: This is why I (usually) don't do nuzlockes
Sometimes my tactics rely on sacrifice of valued members
It's not pretty I know that
Some of the other gym leaders in the making would agree
Some will argue that I don't go far enough
I know the real reason why Lance has three underlevelled Dragonite
He was the champ and should be hard but they had another region after the league so he couldn't be too high of level
But that is poor game design isn't it
summary:
Here he is. The man, the legend! Lance, the Dragon Master! 
Can't wait to beat up his sorry cheater ass. 
Hear me out. Y'all...
body:
Here he is. The man, the legend! Lance, the Dragon Master!

Can’t wait to beat up his sorry cheater ass.

Hear me out. Y'all know that Dragonair evolved pretty late, right? Level 55.

He has three Dragonite, all of them well below level 55. One of them is 50, the others 47.

How did he get his Dragonair to evolve on a lower level? Only one possible explanation for that:

He used the strange radio signal that Team Rocket was broadcasting to evolve them all. You know, the same signal they used to force Magikarp to evolve into Gyarados, which is why there was a red Gyarados in the Lake of Rage.

And why a random trainer had a Gyarados at level 10. But the poor sap didn’t know any better. Lance does. He is a veteran trainer, a legend in the Elite Four. He knows how to stop an evolution, that’s not supposed to happen.

It’s the very same signal we helped shut off in Mahogany by making those poor Electrode faint. He used that signal to evolve his Dragonair.

So his team consists of three (cheated) Dragonite, an Aerodactyl, a Charizard and a Gyarados. Hum, strange, isn’t it? A Gyarados?

Which is the Pokémon he uses to start the fight. I knew that, so my fastest Pokémon with the most effective move was in front.

I would ask you to notice the level difference, but my Thunder Punch actually paralyzed it. The Gyarados is at level 44, so, not so far off.

Granted, Alakazam doesn’t have STAB with Thunder Punch. Still, it has ludicrously high special attack and the attack deals four times the damage to Gyarados. But there it is, still standing (or awkwardly hovering), getting through the paralysis and hitting me with a Hyper Beam.

Alakazam is a glass cannon, so naturally, it went down. But the Gyarados needed to recharge after that and I could take it down with Espeon.

Then, number one of his Dragonite came in. And because Espeon didn’t knew Attract anymore (not useful for this fight), but Swagger, it’s time for a new tactic.

Swagger is a highly risky move. If it doesn’t work, your opponent just got a massive edge against you. But this time, this was exactly what I needed.

See, I had more than enough Revive to do this. Also, Lola my Jynx was strong enough to kill all three of the Dragonite with a single Ice Punch. But, she wasn’t fast enough.

So Espeon would Swagger the Dragonite, get obliterated by Hyper Beam and while Dragonite was recharging, Lola came in and punched it. Then another member of the team would get sacrificed to bring back Espeon, rinse and repeat.

Not a very nice tactic, agreed, but in this case, both necessary and successful.

Both Aerodactyl and Charizard were no problem after that. I needed his Dragonite strong enough to take out Espeon in a single hit with Hyper Beam, so Lola could have a safe switch in.

My Pokémon forgave me for this maneuver. Or was it just the effect of the reviving drug? Either way, they still love me.

And here is my entry number one in the Johto Hall of Fame. Look at these levels! The third Dragonite of Lance was level 50!

And now, we move onward to the Hoenn region to… Wait, what? There is a legend of an extremely strong trainer?

He is training at Mt. Silver? How do I get there to beat his ass?

I need eight more badges, those from the gyms in Kanto? Good thing I still have those.

I can’t use these, they are outdated? I have to get them again?

Alright, for the sake of this extremely strong trainer, Kanto, look out, here I come.

He used the strange radio signal that Team Rocket was broadcasting to evolve them all. You know, the same signal they used to force Magikarp to evolve into Gyarados, which is why there was a red Gyarados in the Lake of Rage.

And why a random trainer had a Gyarados at level 10. But the poor sap didn’t know any better. Lance does. He is a veteran trainer, a legend in the Elite Four. He knows how to stop an evolution, that’s not supposed to happen.

It’s the very same signal we helped shut off in Mahogany by making those poor Electrode faint. He used that signal to evolve his Dragonair.

So his team consists of three (cheated) Dragonite, an Aerodactyl, a Charizard and a Gyarados. Hum, strange, isn’t it? A Gyarados?

Which is the Pokémon he uses to start the fight. I knew that, so my fastest Pokémon with the most effective move was in front.

I would ask you to notice the level difference, but my Thunder Punch actually paralyzed it. The Gyarados is at level 44, so, not so far off.

Granted, Alakazam doesn’t have STAB with Thunder Punch. Still, it has ludicrously high special attack and the attack deals four times the damage to Gyarados. But there it is, still standing (or awkwardly hovering), getting through the paralysis and hitting me with a Hyper Beam.

Alakazam is a glass cannon, so naturally, it went down. But the Gyarados needed to recharge after that and I could take it down with Espeon.

Then, number one of his Dragonite came in. And because Espeon didn’t knew Attract anymore (not useful for this fight), but Swagger, it’s time for a new tactic.

Swagger is a highly risky move. If it doesn’t work, your opponent just got a massive edge against you. But this time, this was exactly what I needed.

See, I had more than enough Revive to do this. Also, Lola my Jynx was strong enough to kill all three of the Dragonite with a single Ice Punch. But, she wasn’t fast enough.

So Espeon would Swagger the Dragonite, get obliterated by Hyper Beam and while Dragonite was recharging, Lola came in and punched it. Then another member of the team would get sacrificed to bring back Espeon, rinse and repeat.

Not a very nice tactic, agreed, but in this case, both necessary and successful.

Both Aerodactyl and Charizard were no problem after that. I needed his Dragonite strong enough to take out Espeon in a single hit with Hyper Beam, so Lola could have a safe switch in.

My Pokémon forgave me for this maneuver. Or was it just the effect of the reviving drug? Either way, they still love me.

And here is my entry number one in the Johto Hall of Fame. Look at these levels! The third Dragonite of Lance was level 50!

And now, we move onward to the Hoenn region to… Wait, what? There is a legend of an extremely strong trainer?

He is training at Mt. Silver? How do I get there to beat his ass?

I need eight more badges, those from the gyms in Kanto? Good thing I still have those.

I can’t use these, they are outdated? I have to get them again?

Alright, for the sake of this extremely strong trainer, Kanto, look out, here I come.
trail.content:
Here he is. The man, the legend! Lance, the Dragon Master!

Can’t wait to beat up his sorry cheater ass.

Hear me out. Y'all know that Dragonair evolved pretty late, right? Level 55.

He has three Dragonite, all of them well below level 55. One of them is 50, the others 47.

How did he get his Dragonair to evolve on a lower level? Only one possible explanation for that:

He used the strange radio signal that Team Rocket was broadcasting to evolve them all. You know, the same signal they used to force Magikarp to evolve into Gyarados, which is why there was a red Gyarados in the Lake of Rage.

And why a random trainer had a Gyarados at level 10. But the poor sap didn’t know any better. Lance does. He is a veteran trainer, a legend in the Elite Four. He knows how to stop an evolution, that’s not supposed to happen.

It’s the very same signal we helped shut off in Mahogany by making those poor Electrode faint. He used that signal to evolve his Dragonair.

So his team consists of three (cheated) Dragonite, an Aerodactyl, a Charizard and a Gyarados. Hum, strange, isn’t it? A Gyarados?

Which is the Pokémon he uses to start the fight. I knew that, so my fastest Pokémon with the most effective move was in front.

I would ask you to notice the level difference, but my Thunder Punch actually paralyzed it. The Gyarados is at level 44, so, not so far off.

Granted, Alakazam doesn’t have STAB with Thunder Punch. Still, it has ludicrously high special attack and the attack deals four times the damage to Gyarados. But there it is, still standing (or awkwardly hovering), getting through the paralysis and hitting me with a Hyper Beam.

Alakazam is a glass cannon, so naturally, it went down. But the Gyarados needed to recharge after that and I could take it down with Espeon.

Then, number one of his Dragonite came in. And because Espeon didn’t knew Attract anymore (not useful for this fight), but Swagger, it’s time for a new tactic.

Swagger is a highly risky move. If it doesn’t work, your opponent just got a massive edge against you. But this time, this was exactly what I needed.

See, I had more than enough Revive to do this. Also, Lola my Jynx was strong enough to kill all three of the Dragonite with a single Ice Punch. But, she wasn’t fast enough.

So Espeon would Swagger the Dragonite, get obliterated by Hyper Beam and while Dragonite was recharging, Lola came in and punched it. Then another member of the team would get sacrificed to bring back Espeon, rinse and repeat.

Not a very nice tactic, agreed, but in this case, both necessary and successful.

Both Aerodactyl and Charizard were no problem after that. I needed his Dragonite strong enough to take out Espeon in a single hit with Hyper Beam, so Lola could have a safe switch in.

My Pokémon forgave me for this maneuver. Or was it just the effect of the reviving drug? Either way, they still love me.

And here is my entry number one in the Johto Hall of Fame. Look at these levels! The third Dragonite of Lance was level 50!

And now, we move onward to the Hoenn region to… Wait, what? There is a legend of an extremely strong trainer?

He is training at Mt. Silver? How do I get there to beat his ass?

I need eight more badges, those from the gyms in Kanto? Good thing I still have those.

I can’t use these, they are outdated? I have to get them again?

Alright, for the sake of this extremely strong trainer, Kanto, look out, here I come.
